Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28**, a custody judgment may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification serves the best interest of the child.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Similarly, **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, § 20** provides that any custody or parenting judgment concerning unmarried parents may be modified upon a showing of material change and best interests.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Provisions of **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 31** establish the statutory framework for joint and sole custody determinations, emphasizing that mutual respect and communication are prerequisites to effective joint custody.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that **custody may be modified when changed circumstances affect the child’s welfare or where cooperation between parents has broken down**. (*See* *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/relocation case decided in the context of an original divorce and custody judgment; it does not involve a post‑judgment modification standard or any discussion of ‘changed circumstances’ or breakdown of parental cooperation as a basis to modify custody. The opinion focuses on best interests and the ‘real advantage’ test under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not on when a court may later modify an existing custody order. Thus it does not support the proposition that custody may be modified upon changed circumstances or failed parental cooperation.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that **custody may be modified when changed circumstances affect the child’s welfare or where cooperation between parents has broken down**. (*See* *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion does address modification of custody and the "changed circumstances" requirement, but it does not state that a breakdown in parental cooperation, by itself, is a basis for modification. Instead, it reiterates that modification requires a material and substantial change in circumstances of sufficient magnitude to affect the child’s welfare and holds that the changes cited there (including the relocation and a court-imposed temporary change) did not meet that standard. The case therefore supports the general changed‑circumstances/welfare test but not the specific proposition about breakdown of cooperation as an independent ground.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

Bluhm v. Bluhm, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (200.proposition: The controlling standard remains the **best interests of the child**, as articulated in *Bluhm v. Bluhm*, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (2007), and *White v. Laingor*, 434 Mass. 64 (2001).
Bluhm v. Bluhm, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (200.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal homicide and joint venture case that does not involve child custody, visitation, adoption, or any domestic relations context where a “best interests of the child” standard would apply. The court never discusses or applies a best-interests standard, nor does it cite Bluhm v. Bluhm or White v. Laingor. Therefore, this case cannot be used as authority for the proposition that the controlling standard is the best interests of the child.
Bluhm v. Bluhm, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (200.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt available. The opinion concerns murder, jury instructions on manslaughter and intoxication, and a motion for new trial; it does not mention child custody, visitation, or a best-interests-of-the-child standard.]

White v. Laingor, 434 Mass. 64 (2001).proposition: The controlling standard remains the **best interests of the child**, as articulated in *Bluhm v. Bluhm*, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (2007), and *White v. Laingor*, 434 Mass. 64 (2001).
White v. Laingor, 434 Mass. 64 (2001).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that judges must determine and explicitly find that agreements affecting child support are consistent with the “best interests of the child,” and emphasizes that this standard is grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child. While the context is enforceability of a child-support/adoption agreement, the court clearly identifies the best-interests standard as the governing benchmark, consistent with how the later Bluhm decision frames the controlling standard. Thus, the case properly supports the proposition that the best interests of the child remain the controlling standard.
White v. Laingor, 434 Mass. 64 (2001).relevant_excerpt: “However, before upholding such agreements, judges must be satisfied that the best interests of the child are not compromised. … Therefore, the probate judge must review the arrangement and explicitly conclude that the agreed terms are consistent with ‘the best interests of the children.’ G. L. c. 119A, § 1. … As we have said, ‘the best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000).”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Courts have recognized that ongoing parental conflict and disparagement can constitute a sufficient change in circumstances. (*See* *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000)).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a relocation / removal case focused on the standard for permitting removal when parents share joint physical custody, and on application of a best‑interests analysis in that context. While the opinion mentions that the child was “emotionally harmed” by the parents’ ongoing conflict, it does not treat parental conflict or disparagement as a “change in circumstances,” nor does it analyze or hold that such conflict itself constitutes a sufficient change in circumstances for modification. The case therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition about “change in circumstances.”
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “In addition to the developmental issues, the judge found that the mother’s children claimed one of them was inappropriately touched by the son of the mother’s new husband. The allegation caused considerable acrimony between the mother and father. This tension left the child, who subsequently recanted and then reasserted his claim of abuse, feeling ‘scared about his role in the family’ and ‘emotionally harmed’ by his parents’ ongoing conflict.”

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: Courts have recognized that ongoing parental conflict and disparagement can constitute a sufficient change in circumstances. (*See* *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000)).
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: Williams v. Massa is about initial divorce, property division, support, and custody, and only touches on custody modification procedure in one narrow respect: it holds that a change in custody must occur via a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The opinion does not discuss what constitutes a ‘material change in circumstances’ for modification, nor does it address ongoing parental conflict or disparagement as a ground for modification. Thus it does not support the specific proposition that ongoing parental conflict/disparagement can constitute a sufficient change in circumstances.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

Malachi M. v. Quentin N., 484 Mass. 418.proposition: Interference with another parent’s custody or parenting time is further grounds for modification. (*See* *Rosenthal v. Maney*, supra; *Malachi M. v. Quentin N.*, 484 Mass. 418 (2020)).

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts appellate precedent holds that failure to cooperate in joint legal custody decisions may warrant granting sole legal custody to one parent. (*See* *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The case directly discusses when joint legal custody is appropriate, emphasizing that it requires parents who can agree on basic child-rearing issues and want to cooperate in making decisions. The court affirms the trial judge’s decision that, because these parents were unable to cooperate and had fundamental disagreements on major child-rearing issues, joint custody would be harmful and sole custody to one parent (the mother) was appropriate. This aligns with the proposition that failure to cooperate in joint legal custody decisions may warrant granting sole legal custody to one parent.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … Although complete agreement between parents to implement joint custody may not be necessary… joint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions… The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts appellate precedent holds that failure to cooperate in joint legal custody decisions may warrant granting sole legal custody to one parent. (*See* *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly notes that the parties do not contest the judge’s conclusion that joint legal custody was inappropriate due to their inability to communicate and work together on major decisions about the child’s well-being, and it cites Rolde v. Rolde for that proposition. By affirming an award of sole legal custody to the mother on this basis, the SJC recognizes and applies the principle that a failure or inability to cooperate in joint legal custody decisions can warrant granting sole legal custody to one parent.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The parties do not contest the judge’s conclusion that joint legal custody was not appropriate in light of the past inability of the parents to communicate productively about and jointly work together in making major decisions concerning Kali’s well being. Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404-405 (1981). See G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a).”
